source.raw_text:
The Sandbag Strict Press is a compound, full-body movement building upper-body pushing strength (delts, triceps, chest), core stability (abs, lower back), and leg drive, with the unstable sandbag load enhancing stabilizer muscles and functional strength compared to barbells, forcing greater core engagement and shoulder girdle stabilization through the entire pressing pattern from front rack to overhead lockout. [1, 2, 3, 4]  
Muscles Worked 

• Primary Movers (Pushing): 

    • Deltoids (Shoulders): Especially the anterior (front) delts, but also lateral and rear delts for stability. 
    • Triceps: Extend the elbow to lock out the weight overhead. 
    • Pectorals (Chest): Assist in pressing. 

• Stabilizers & Support: 

    • Core (Abs, Obliques, Lower Back): Braces the spine and pelvis to prevent arching and maintain a stable torso. 
    • Traps (Trapezius): Help stabilize the shoulder girdle. 
    • Upper Back (Rhomboids, Lats): Support shoulder stability. 
    • Glutes & Legs: Provide a solid base and drive power from the ground up (leg drive). 
    • Forearms & Grip: Hold the sandbag securely. [1, 2, 3, 5, 6, 7]  

Movement Patterns (Pushing Pattern) 

1. Setup (Clean): Lift the sandbag to the front rack position (resting on shoulders/chest). 
2. Descent (Eccentric): Brace core, maintain upright chest, and keep the sandbag stable as you transition from front rack to the start. 
3. Press (Concentric): 

    • Drive with legs (slight dip/stomp). 
    • Drive the sandbag upward, keeping elbows in. 
    • Drive your head through at the top (like shrugging forward) to get it overhead. 
    • Lock out elbows with biceps by ears. 

4. Return (Eccentric): Control the descent back to the front rack position, resetting for the next rep. [6, 7, 8, 9]  

Sandbag Specifics 

• Instability: The shifting weight forces greater stabilizer muscle recruitment in the shoulders and core. 
• Unpredictable Load: Requires constant adjustment, improving neuromuscular coordination. [4, 10]  

**Citations:**
